bad.institution: ashmolean birmingham britishmuseum cornwall fogg ngvic tate

titlestmt.title: Illustrations to Dante's "Divine Comedy" : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

filedesc.extent: XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 65KB; 16 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 135KB to 1000KB
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of Blake's water color and engraved illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy. Along with the illustrations to Edward Young's Night Thoughts, the poetry of Thomas Gray, and John Milton's poems, the Dante series of 102 water colors are among Blake's most important series of illustrations to another poet. Although he engraved only 7 of the designs from the water color series, these plates show that Blake continued innovative work as a line engraver into the final days of his life. The water colors can be found in the Archive by moving through the following categories: Works in the Archive, Non-Illuminated Materials, Drawings and Paintings, and Water Color Drawings. The engravings can be found by moving through the following categories: Works in the Archive, Non-Illuminated Materials, Separate Prints and Prints in Series, Plates Designed and Engraved by Blake.
The water colors were commissioned by John Linnell, the chief patron of Blake's final years. Although Linnell did not begin to pay for the designs until December 1825, at the rate of about 1 pound a week, Blake probably began work on the drawings by the fall of 1824. They were left at Blake's death in 1827 in various stages of completion, ranging from pencil sketches to highly finished water colors. Most show an expressive freedom in the handling of color washes far greater than Blake's earlier water colors. In 1826, Blake began to engrave large plates based on 7 of the designs; these were also left incomplete at his death. Like Blake's Job engravings, the Dante plates are pure line engravings without preliminary etching. The water colors remained in Linnell's collection and estate until their sale at auction in 1918. Through a scheme organized by the National Arts-Collections Fund, they were dispersed among 7 participating institutions: Ashmolean Museum (3 designs), Birmingham Museums & Art Gallery (6 designs), British Museum (13 designs), Fogg Art Museum (23 designs) National Gallery of Victoria (36 designs), Royal Institution of Cornwall (1 design), and Tate Collection (20 designs). The engravings, first printed for sale in 1838, are reproduced from a set in the collection of Robert N. Essick.
We have also taken this opportunity to publish four more Collection Lists: Ashmolean Museum, J. Paul Getty Museum, Royal Institution of Cornwall, and Tate Collection. The last in this group is one of the largest and finest gatherings of Blake's drawings, water colors, and paintings. These lists can be found, along with the eighteen others previously published, under Resources for Further Research on the Archive's main Table of Contents (Home Page).
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Library of Congress, the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

header.userestrict:
Copyright © 2005 by Morris Eaves, Robert N. Essick, and Joseph Viscomi, all rights reserved. Items in the Archive may be shared in accordance with the Fair Use provisions of U.S. copyright law. Redistribution or republication on other terms, in any medium, requires express written consent from the editors and advance notification of the publisher. Permission to reproduce the graphic images in this archive has been granted by the owners of the originals for this publication only.
This image copyright © 2014 Ashmolean Museum (Objects 89, 96, 100), Birmingham Museums & Art Gallery (Objects 2, 10, 44, 68, 84, 95), British Museum (Objects 21, 22, 27, 40, 47, 51, 53, 71, 75, 85, 90, 93, 99), Fogg Art Museum, President and Fellows of Harvard College (Objects 6, 7, 11, 17, 18, 23, 24, 28, 31, 32, 34, 35, 43, 45, 55, 57, 64, 67, 69, 70, 73, 80, 86), National Gallery of Victoria (Objects 1, 5, 9, 13, 15, 16, 19, 20, 26, 29, 30, 33, 37-39, 41, 49, 52, 54, 58-60, 62, 65, 66, 72, 77-79, 87, 88, 92, 94, 97, 98, 102), The Royal Institution of Cornwall (Object 82), Tate Collection (Objects 3, 4, 8, 12, 14, 25, 36, 42, 46, 48, 50, 56, 61, 63, 74, 76, 81, 83, 91, 101).

changestmt.change: Conversion to XML and Blake Archive Description DTD 2004
changestmt.respstmt: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Technical Editor: Andrea LaueConversion: Aziza Technology AssociatesProject Manager: Justin Van KleeckProject Assistants: Christopher N. Jackson, Kari Kraus, Wesley N. Raabe, Wayne C. Ripley, William Shaw

objinfo.objsize: each approximately 37.0 x 52.5 cm. (horizontal format) or 52.5 x 37.0 cm. (vertical format)
objinfo.leafsize: each approximately 37.0 x 52.5 cm. (horizontal format) or 52.5 x 37.0 cm. (vertical format)
objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water colors over pencilObjects 27, 32, 71, 73, 86, and 93 are basically pencil drawings with, in some cases, pen and ink additions or very slight touches of color.
objinfo.watermark: WELGAR 1796 or a fleur-de-lis with WEEach leaf appears to be half of a sheet with the WELGAR watermark on one half and the fleur-de-lis countermark on the other half. The watermark or countermark cannot be seen on the water colors that are pasted down to a backing mat, but are very probably present.
objinfo.pennednumbers: All but Objects 14, 22, 27, 44, 50, 57, 97, 98, 100, and 102 are inscribed with the number of the canto or cantos of Dante's poem illustrated by the design. Object 57 is inscribed "95."The sheets bear inscriptions on their versos, including two sets of numbers that would appear to be attempts to indicate the proper sequence of the designs. None of these verso inscriptions are by Blake.
objinfo.binding: The designs may have been bound at one time, but are now disbound and dispersed.

provenance.name: Ashmolean Museum (Objects 89, 96, 100), Birmingham Museums & Art Gallery (Objects 2, 10, 44, 68, 84, 95), British Museum (Objects 21, 22, 27, 40, 47, 51, 53, 71, 75, 85, 90, 93, 99), Fogg Art Museum, President and Fellows of Harvard College (Objects 6, 7, 11, 17, 18, 23, 24, 28, 31, 32, 34, 35, 43, 45, 55, 57, 64, 67, 69, 70, 73, 80, 86), National Gallery of Victoria (Objects 1, 5, 9, 13, 15, 16, 19, 20, 26, 29, 30, 33, 37-39, 41, 49, 52, 54, 58-60, 62, 65, 66, 72, 77-79, 87, 88, 92, 94, 97, 98, 102), The Royal Institution of Cornwall (Object 82), Tate Collection (Objects 3, 4, 8, 12, 14, 25, 36, 42, 46, 48, 50, 56, 61, 63, 74, 76, 81, 83, 91, 101).
provenance.note: Acquired directly from Blake by John Linnell, who commissioned the designs; sold from Linnell's estate, Christie's, 15 March 1918, lot 148 (£7665 to Alec Martin acting for the National Art-Collections Fund, which divided the designs by prior arrangement amongst the seven institutions now owning the Dante water colors).

repository.addressline: Courtney Library & Cornish History Research Centre

desc.objtitle: Dante Running from the Three BeastsDante Running from the Three Beasts is Rescued by Virgil, Object 1 (Butlin 812.1)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "4" top right, and "No 2 next at p 6" top center. The latter inscription was also partly erased from the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: LagoLines 1-2 are faintly written in the sea between the lower leg of the hovering figure and the lower torso of the figure striding on the ground.

l.note: Line 3 is written on a diagonal descending from left to right on the ground below and to the right of the right foot of the striding figure.

desc.objtitle: The Mission of Virgil, Object 2 (Butlin 812.3)

lg.l: The Angry God of thisWorld &Paradise"World" is written over another, illegible inscription that ends with the word "Paradise."

l.note: The line is written diagonally, rising from left to right, just to the left of the top figure's right hand.
Lines 4-5 are written diagonally, descending from left to right, on each side of the spiral descending from the left hand of the top figure.

desc.objtitle: Dante and Virgil Penetrating the ForestDante and Virgil Enter the Wood, Object 3 (Butlin 812.2)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "92" top right, "N 37 next at p. 71" top center, and "Hell Canto 22" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Inscription over Hell-Gate, Object 4 (Butlin 812.4)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "3" top right, and "No 1 next at p 4" top center. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Lasciate orni speranza voi che in entrateThe final two words in line 1 are almost illegible; our reading is conjectural. The final two words in Dante's text are "che entrate."
Leave every Hope you who in Enter

desc.objtitle: The Vestibule of Hell and the Souls Mustering to Cross the Acheron, Object 5 (Butlin 812.5)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "7" top right, and "No 30 next at p 64" top center, with the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Charon and the Condemned Souls, Object 6 (Butlin 812.6)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "50" over chalk, top right, and "Pg Canto 5 & 6" along the right margin, crossed through. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Homer Bearing the Sword and His Companions, Object 7 (Butlin 812.7)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "16" top right, and "N50 next at p 20" top center, with the latter partly erased from the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

l.note: Each of these words is written on its own diagonal, rising from left to right, below the top margin of the design.

lg.l: TerrestrialLines 3-4 are written above a circle (the sun?), line 5 within the circle, and line 6 below the circle. They evidently form a syntactic cluster.
It is an Island in Limbo
Every thing in Dantes Comedia shews That for TyrannicalLines 8-11 are written upper center within the second circle.
Purposes he has made This World the Foundation
of All & the Goddess Nature Memory & not Imagination the Holy GhostTwo carets below the line indicate the insertion of "Memory" and "Imagination."

is his InspirerThese words may be intended to be an insert after "Memory" (line 10), itself an insert. If so, then line 10 would read, with all three inserts, "of All & the Goddess Nature Memory is his Inspirer not Imagination the Holy Ghost."
as Poor ChurchillLines 12-14 would appear to be an extension of the comments in lines 8-11.
round Purgatory is ParadiseLines 15-29 descend through the right side of the second circle.
MoonLines 30-38 are written as a vertical list near the right margin of the design.

l.hi: Swedenborg does the same in saying that in this World is the Ultimate of Heaven
l.note: Lines 39-40 are inscribed in an arc descending through the third circle toward the right.

l.hi: This is the most damnable Falsehood of Satan and his Anti-christ

lg.l: HomerThis inscription appears in the fifth circle, immediately above the head of the large figure lower center.

l.note: These numbers for the circles of hell begin on the rock, center left, and extend toward a point above the raised left hand of the figure immediately to the left of the large central figure. Each inscription is written on its own diagonal, rising from left to right, in conformity with the arc of the circles.

lg.l: SatanThis inscription appears in the seventh circle, just left of the face of the large figure lower center.

l.note: These numbers for the circles of hell are inscribed above the head of the figure immediately to the left of the large central figure. Each number is written on its own diagonal, rising from left to right, in conformity with the arc of the circles.

desc.objtitle: Homer and the Ancient Poets, Object 8 (Butlin 812.8)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "14" top right, "N 13 next at p 78" top center, and "N13 next a p 78" in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Minos, Object 9 (Butlin 812.9)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "10" top right, and "No 16 next at p. 44" top center, with the latter in the center of the sheet partly erased. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Circle of the Lustful: Francesca Da RiminiThe Whirlwind of Lovers, Object 10 (Butlin 812.10)
The Circle of the Gluttons with Cerberus, Object 11 (Butlin 812.11 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "ENOCH" upper center, and "Enoch" lower left. The first of these inscriptions might be by Blake.

desc.objtitle: First Version of Cerberus, Object 12 (Butlin 812.12)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "29" top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Second Version of Cerberus, Object 13 (Butlin 812.13)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "19" top right, and "Pg Canto 25" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Plutus, Object 14 (Butlin 812.14)

lg.l: MoneyThe word is inscribed on the sack of coins below the extended right hand of the figure lower right.

desc.objtitle: The Goddess of Fortune, Object 15 (Butlin 812.16)

objnote.p: The lower right corner of the design bears the collection stamp of the National Gallery of Victoria. Inscribed on the verso, "55" top right, "No 19 next a p 80" top center, and "HELL Canto 12" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: CelestialLines 1-2 are written in a circle, representing the heavens or a celestial globe, left of center. The inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.
TerrestrialLines 3-4 are written in a circle, representing the earth or a terrestrial globe, right of center. The inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

l.hi: The hole of a shit house
l.note: Lines 5-6 are written in an arc above the lower figure.

l.hi: The Goddess Fortune is the devils servant ready to Kiss any ones Arse

desc.objtitle: The Stygian Lake with the Ireful Sinners FightingThe Stygian Lake with the Angry Sinners Fighting, Object 16 (Butlin 812.15)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "6" top right, "No 4 next at p 49" and "14 x 49" top center, and "HELL Canto 3" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: The Stygian Lake Canto 7This inscription is very faint and may have been almost completely erased. Our reading is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: Dante and Virgil about to Pass the Stygian LakeDante and Virgil about to Cross towards the City of Dis, Object 17 (Butlin 812.17)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "15" top right, "N7 next at p. 9" across the top, and an erased inscription in the center of the sheet, probably the same as the one across the top. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Canto 6This inscription is very faint and covered with gray wash. Our reading is conjectural.
Stygian LakeThis inscription is written on the water left of the boat's sail.
HELL Canto 7This ink inscription is offset slightly above its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle: Virgil Repelling Filippo Argenti from the Boat of Phlegyas, Object 18 (Butlin 812.18 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "77" top left, "No 46 next at p 74" across the top, and "25," partly erased bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: 22This inscription is very faint and covered with gray wash. Our reading is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: The Angel Crossing the StyxThe City of Dis and the Angel Crossing the Stygian Lake, Object 19 (Butlin 812.19 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "62" partly erased top right, and "Canto 24 v 60" partly erased bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Hell Canto 8This inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

desc.objtitle: The Angel at the Gate of Dis, Object 20 (Butlin 812.20 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "11" top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Dante Conversing with Farinata Degli Uberti, Object 21 (Butlin 812.21)
The Circles of HellScheme of the Circles of Hell, Object 22 (Butlin 812.101 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "9" lower right, "6" center left, "N 8 next at p 17" center right, "Hell. Carthew No Canto number. Entitled 'Hell Circles' at end of list of Hell in Christie's Catalogue of Sale" upper right, and "Debris" top left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Jesus as if heThe word "as" has been crossed through, indicating a deletion, with "For" in line 5 the evident substitute.
of the Bible neither in the
Formed by the devil Him self & So I understand it to have been
ourLines 17-18 are very faint; our readings are conjectural.
GeryonThe final word is very faint; our reading is conjectural.
Most Likely Dante describes the 7 8 & 9 Circles
7in Canto XI v 18The "7" indicates the number of this circle of hell and is probably not syntactically related to words on this line.

3 Compartments thyCentaursThe second word ("thy") is very faint; our reading is conjectural. The last word ("Centaurs") indicates a creature identified with this circle of hell and may not be syntactically related to other words on this line.
The City of Dis seems to occupy the space
between the Fifth & Sixth MinotaursThe last word ("Minotaurs") indicates a creature identified with this circle of hell and may not be syntactically related to other words on this line.
Circles or perhaps it occupies both Circles
Lesser CircleCity of DisThe last three words ("City of Dis") indicate the name for this circle of hell and are not syntactically related to other words in this line.

l.note: Lines 44-46 are written vertically, reading from top to bottom, just inside the right margin. The continuation of this passage in lines 47-48 is written vertically, reading from bottom to top, left of lines 44-46.

l.hi: when viewed from Hells Gate which ought to be
l.note: The final four words of line 45 and line 48 appear to be in a different hand and may not be by Blake.

l.hi: But right when Viewed from Purgatory after they have passed the Center
In Equivocal Worlds Up & down are Equivocal

lg.l: is not of the Father but

desc.objtitle: The Minotaur, Object 23 (Butlin 812.22 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "83" top left, "No 29 next at p 82 this should be 35" in the center, with the "28" deleted by the "29," and "HELL Canto 18 v 80" along the left margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: MIASTAMUThis inscription is written, rather obscurely, on the front of the altar in the center of the composition. Neither "A" is crossed; the "M" (if it is an "M") is oddly shaped. There may be another inscription, just barely indicated, on the right side of the altar.
7The number is awkwardly formed and may simply be an accidental conjunction of two chalk marks.

desc.objtitle: The Centaurs and the River of Blood, Object 24 (Butlin 812.23)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "56" top right, "Paradiso Canto 30" bottom right, and "Parad Canto 30" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Wood of the Self-Murderers: The Harpies and the SuicidesThe Wood of the Self-Violators: The Harpies and the Suicides, Object 25 (Butlin 812.24)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "N21 next at p. 86" top center, the same vertically in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 13" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Hell-Hounds Hunting the Destroyers of Their Own Goods, Object 26 (Butlin 812.25)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "78" bottom right, "No 14 next at p 68" bottom center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "HELL Canto 8" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Unidentified Scene in HellReclining Male Figure, Object 27 (Butlin 812.100)
The Blasphemers with the Usurers and the Sodomites, Object 28 (Butlin 812.26)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "85" top left, "Hell Canto 18" along the right margin, and an erased inscription, probably repeating the inscription on the right margin, in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Capaneus the Blasphemer, Object 29 (Butlin 812.27)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "43" top right, "N 27 next at p 83" top center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "43 Hell Canto 17" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Symbolic Figure of the Course of Human History Described by VirgilThe Course of Human History Personified, Object 30 (Butlin 812.28 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "54" top right, "N 12 next at p 6" top center, with the "6" written over a partly erased "14," "No 12 next at p 14" in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 7" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Hell Canto 14Lines 1-2 are very faint and may have been partly erased. Our reading of the second word in each line is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: The Punishment of Jacopo Rusticucci and His CompanionsJacopo Rusticucci and His Companions, Object 31 (Butlin 812.29)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "88" top right, and "Paradise Canto 27 v 25" partly erased along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

l.note: The number, obscured by blue wash, is written on a diagonal rising from right to left.

desc.objtitle: The Usurers, Object 32 (Butlin 812.30)
Geryon Conveying Dante and Virgil Down Towards MalebolgeGeryon Carries Dante and Virgil Towards Malebolge, Object 33 (Butlin 812.31 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "44" top right, "N 17 next at p 84" top center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 10" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Demons Tormenting the Panders and Seducers in MalebolgeDemons Tormenting the Pimps and Seducers in Malebolge, Object 34 (Butlin 812.32)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "84" top left, "N18 next at p 55" just below the top margin, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "Minotaur. Hell Canto 12" partly erased bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: HELLLines 1-2 are inscribed on the wall just below the center of the design.

desc.objtitle: Dante and Virgil Gazing into the Ditch of the FlatterersDante and Virgil Looking into the Ditch of the Flatterers, Object 35 (Butlin 812.33)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "13" top right, "N6 next at p 15" below the top margin, and "Hell Canto 4" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Hell Canto 18This inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

desc.objtitle: The Simoniac Pope, Object 36 (Butlin 812.35)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "8" top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Necromancers and AugersThe Necromancers, Object 37 (Butlin 812.36)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "65" top right, and "N 61, last in the Inferno unless...Dante lifted by Virgil..." in the center of the sheet, partly erased. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Hell Canto 20This inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

desc.objtitle: The Devil Carrying the Lucchese Magistrate to the Boiling Pitch Pool of Corrupt OfficialsA Devil Carrying the Lucchese Peculator to the Lake of Boiling Pitch, Object 38 (Butlin 812.37)

objnote.p: The lower left corner of the design bears the collection stamp of the National Gallery of Victoria. Inscribed on the verso, "68" top right, "No 15 next at p 10" top center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 8" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Devils Under the Bridge, Object 39 (Butlin 812.34)

objnote.p: The lower right corner of the design bears the collection stamp of the National Gallery of Victoria. Inscribed on the verso, "82 N 30 next at p 64" top center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "HELL Canto 22" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Virgil Abashing the DevilsVirgil Converses with the Devil Malacoda, Object 40 (Butlin 812.38)
The Devils Setting Out with Dante and VirgilDante and Virgil Set Out Accompanied by the Devils, Object 41 (Butlin 812.39 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "52" top right, "N 45 next at p 77" top center, and "Hell Canto 25 Cacus" partly erased along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Devils with Dante and Virgil by the Side of the PoolDante and Virgil with the Devils by the Lake of Pitch, Object 42 (Butlin 812.40)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "81" top left. This inscription is not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Ciampolo the Barrator Tormented by the DevilsCiampolo Tormented by the Devils, Object 43 (Butlin 812.41)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "31" top right, and "Pg Canto 22" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: HELL Canto 22 line 70The full inscription was first written in pencil, and then "Hell Canto 22" was over-written in ink.

desc.objtitle: The Baffled Devils FightingThe Devils Fighting, Object 44 (Butlin 812.42)
Dante and Virgil Escaping from the DevilsDante and Virgil Escape from the Devils, Object 45 (Butlin 812.43 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "70" top left, and "Hell Canto 24 v. 30" partly erased bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Hypocrites with Caiaphas, Object 46 (Butlin 812.44 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "71" top left, "N38 next at p 72" top center, the same in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 23 v 40" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Laborious Passage Along the Rocks, Object 47 (Butlin 812.45 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "86" top right, "N 22 next at p 42" top center, "Paradiso Canto 26 v 81" bottom left, "3" left center, and "14 hell Canto 14" partly erased top left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: 87This inscription is faint and may have been partly erased.

l.note: This line is written vertically, reading from bottom to top, in the upper right margin. The inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

desc.objtitle: The Laborious Passage Along the RocksContinuing Passage Along the Rocks, Object 48 (Butlin 812.46)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "69" top left, "N 40 next at p 75" top center, and "Hell Canto 24 v 60" bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: HELL Canto 24v 30"v 30" is very faint; our reading is conjectural. It forms a syntactic unit with line 1 and not with line 2.

desc.objtitle: The Thieves and the Serpents, Object 49 (Butlin 812.47 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "74 No 47 next at p 73" bottom center, the same partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Canto 25" top center partly erased. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Punishment of the Thieves, Object 50 (Butlin 812.102)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "80" top left, and "N 20 next at p 79" top center. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

l.note: The word is written vertically, reading from bottom to top. This inscription is faint, in part because it is covered with blue wash.

desc.objtitle: The Serpent Attacking Vanni FucciThe Serpent Biting Vanni Fucci, Object 51 (Butlin 812.48)

l.note: The line is written vertically, reading from bottom to top. This inscription is very faint; it may have been partly erased. Blue-gray wash obscures the final word.

desc.objtitle: Vanni Fucci Making Figs Against GodVanni Fucci Makes a Blasphemous Gesture, Object 52 (Butlin 812.49 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "34" top right, and "Pg Canto 9" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Centaur CacusThe Centaur Cacus Threatens Vanni Fucci, Object 53 (Butlin 812.50)

lg.l: HELL Canto 25The ink inscription, particularly the number, is offset to the left of its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle: The Six-Footed Serpent Attacking Agnolo BrunelleschiThe Six-Footed Serpent Attacks Agnello Brunelleschi, Object 54 (Butlin 812.51 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "76" bottom left, "N 42 next at p 95" bottom center, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Vanni Fucci Hell Canto 24" partly erased along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Agnolo Brunelleschi Half Transformed by the SerpentAgnello Brunelleschi Transformed by the Serpent, Object 55 (Butlin 812.52)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "73" top left, "N 48 next at p. 57" at the top, "Hell Canto 25" partly erased along the right margin, and fragments of an erased inscription (probably the same as the one along the right margin) in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

l.note: The word is written vertically, reading from bottom to top. The inscription is very faint; it may have been partly erased. Our reading is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: The Serpent Attacking Buoso DonatiThe Serpent Attacks Buoso De' Donati, Object 56 (Butlin 812.53 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "72" top center, "N39 next at p 69" top center, the latter in the center of the sheet, and "HELL Canto 23" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Buoso Donati Transformed into a Serpent; Francesco De' Cavalcanti Retransformed from a Serpent into a ManThe Transformation of Serpent into Man Completed, Object 57 (Butlin 812.54)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "94" bottom left, "7" at the right margin, and "No 11 next at p 54" partly erased in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

l.note: The number is written vertically, reading from bottom to top.

desc.objtitle: Ulysses and Diomed Swathed in the Same FlameUlysses and Diomedes Wrapped in the Same Flame, Object 58 (Butlin 812.55)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "58" top right, and "Pg canto 13" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Schismatics and Sowers of Discord: MohammedThe Schismatics and Sowers of Discord: Mohammed and Ali, Object 59 (Butlin 812.56 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "17" top right, "N 9 next at p 18" top center, "No 9 next at p 18" partly erased in the center of the sheet, "One of the whirlwinds of love" center right, and "Hell Canto 5 Paulo and Francesca" bottom right. These last two inscriptions apparently refer to the pencil drawing on the verso and not to the water color on the recto. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Canto 28The inscription is extremely faint; it may have been partly erased. Our reading is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: The Schismatics and Sowers of Discord: Mosca De' Lamberti and Bertrand De BornThe Schismatics and Sowers of Discord: Bertrand De Born and Mosca De'Lamberti, Object 60 (Butlin 812.57)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "21" top right, "N 57 next at p 22" top center, and the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Hell Canto 28The inscription is very faint; it may have been partly erased. Our reading of the second word is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: The Pit of Disease: The FalsifiersThe Alchemists and Forgers, Object 61 (Butlin 812.58)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "28" top right, and "For this see P 62" top center. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Pit of Disease: Gianni Schicchi and MyrrhaThe Counterfeiters of Persons: Gianni Schicchi and Myrrha, Object 62 (Butlin 812.59 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "63" top right, and "Pg Canto 4" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Primaeval Giants Sunk in the SoilThe Primeval Giants, Object 63 (Butlin 812.60)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "27" top right, "Hell Canto 29" bottom left, and "N52 next at p 25" in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: HELL Canto 31This ink inscription is offset slightly to the left of its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle: The Complaint of the Giant NimrodThe Giant Nimrod, Object 64 (Butlin 812.61 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "26" top right, "N33 next at p 25" along the top margin, and with fragments of an erased inscription, probably the same as the one along the top margin, in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Ephialtes and Two Other TitansEphialtes and Two Other Giants, Object 65 (Butlin 812.62 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "46" top right, "No 60 next at p 65" top center, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 32" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Antaeus Setting Down Dante and Virgil in the Last Circle of HellAntaeus Sets Down Dante and Virgil in the Ninth Circle, Object 66 (Butlin 812.63)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "2" top right, "N 3 next at p 3" top center, and the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Circle of Traitors: The Alberti Brothers, Object 67 (Butlin 812.64)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "22" top right, and "N58 next at p 47 this should be N61" in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: VirgildanteThese names are inscribed just to the left ("Virgil") and above and slightly to the right ("dante") of the heads of the two figures standing on the left.
HELL Canto 32This ink inscription is offset slightly above its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle: Dante Striking Against Bocca Degli AbatiDante Strikes Against Bocca Degli Abbati, Object 68 (Butlin 812.65)
Dante Tugging at Bocca's HairDante Grabs Bocca Degli Abbati by the Hair, Object 69 (Butlin 812.66 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "47" and "Hell Canto 33" bottom right, and "N 59 next at p 46" top left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Canto 32The inscription is very faint and covered with gray wash. Our reading of the number is conjectural.
UgolinoThis faint inscription is above the head of the figure on the left biting into another figure's head or neck.

desc.objtitle: Ugolino Relating His DeathUgolino Tells of His Fate, Object 70 (Butlin 812.67)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "48" top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Ugolino and His Sons in Prison, Object 71 (Butlin 812.68)
Lucifer, Object 72 (Butlin 812.69 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "66" top right, "N 33 next at p 51" top right, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 21" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Dante with Virgil and Cato, Object 73 (Butlin 812.71)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "60" and "Pg. Canto 1" top right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Canto 1The inscription is very faint. A few pencil strokes below this line may be another inscription, but it is illegible.
Dante CantoThe inscription is extremely faint; our reading is conjectural.
CatoThis faint inscription appears above the nimbus surrounding the head of the figure on the right.

desc.objtitle: Virgil Girding Dante's Brow with a RushVirgil Girds Dante's Brow with a Reed, Object 74 (Butlin 812.70)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "61" top left, and "Pg Canto 2" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Angel in the Boat Departing after Wafting Over the Souls for PurgatoryThe Angelic Boat Returning after Depositing Souls on the Shore with Cato Chiding, Object 75 (Butlin 812.72)

lg.l: Purga Canto 2The inscription is very faint; it may have been partly erased. Our reading is conjectural.
CatoThe inscription appears above the head of the left-most figure.

desc.objtitle: The Ascent of the Mountain of PurgatoryThe Ascent on the Way to Purgatory, Object 76 (Butlin 812.74)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "Pg Canto 8" bottom right. This inscription is not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Rest on the Mountain Leading to PurgatoryThe Rest on the Way to Purgatory, Object 77 (Butlin 812.73 recto)

objnote.p: The lower left corner of the design bears part of the collection stamp of the National Gallery of Victoria. Inscribed on the verso, "64" top right, "N 31 next at p 67" top center, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 20" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Souls of Those Who Only Repented at the Point of DeathThe Souls of Those Who Only Repented at Point of Death, Object 78 (Butlin 812.75 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "51" top right, "N 34 next at p 83" top center, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 21" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Lawn with the Kings and AngelsThe Valley of Negligent Rulers, Object 79 (Butlin 812.76)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "33" top right, "N 44 next at p 52" top center, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Vanni Fucci Hell Canto 25" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: Purg Canto 8The inscription is extremely faint; it was probably partly erased. Our reading of the words before the number is highly conjectural.

desc.objtitle: Lucia Carrying Dante in His SleepLucia Carries Dante Towards the Entrance to Purgatory, Object 80 (Butlin 812.77)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "42" top right, "N23 next at p 52" just below the top margin, and "Capaneus Hell Canto 14" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: P-g Canto 9This ink inscription is offset slightly to the left of its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle: Dante and Virgil Approaching the Angel Who Guards the Entrance of PurgatoryDante and Virgil Before the Angelic Guardian of the Gate of Purgatory, Object 81 (Butlin 812.78)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "35" top right, and "Pg Canto 9" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Angel Marking Dante with the Sevenfold PThe Angel Marking Dante's Forehead, Object 82 (Butlin 812.79)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "36" and "Pg Canto 9" top right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Rock Sculptured with the Recovery of the Ark and the AnnunciationDante and Virgil Contemplate the Sculptures in the Rock, Object 83 (Butlin 812.80)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "38" top right, and "Pg Canto 12" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Proud Under Their Enormous LoadsThe Proud Bearing Their Heavy Loads, Object 84 (Butlin 812.81)

lg.l: P-g Canto 10This ink inscription is written over a faint (and perhaps slightly erased) inscription in pencil that is now illegible. At least part of the pencil inscription may simply be the under-writing of the ink inscription.

desc.objtitle: The Angel Descending at the Close of the Circle of the ProudThe Proud of History on the Path and the Angel Descending, Object 85 (Butlin 812.82)

l.note: The line is written on a diagonal rising from bottom to top

lg.l: Pg Canto 12The inscription is extremely faint; it may have been partly erased. Our reading of the words before the number is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: The Terrace of Envious SoulsThe Souls of the Envious, Object 86 (Butlin 812.83)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "59" and "Pg Canto 1" top right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: SoulsThis faint inscription appears above and to the right of the heads of the two left-most figures. Our reading is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: The Angel Inviting Dante to Enter the FireThe Angel Invites Dante to Enter the Flames, Object 87 (Butlin 812.84)

objnote.p: The lower left corner of the design bears part of the collection stamp of the National Gallery of Victoria. Inscribed on the verso, "40" top right, and "Pg Canto 27" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: P-g Canto 27Parts of this ink inscription are offset a little above and to the left of its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle: Dante at the Moment of Entering the FireDante at the Point of Entering the Flames, Object 88 (Butlin 812.85)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "20" top right, "N 51 next at p 27" top center, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 28" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Dante and Statius Sleeping with Virgil WatchingDante and Statius Sleep While Virgil Watches, Object 89 (Butlin 812.86)

lg.l: Leah andLines 1-2 are written in the upper-right quadrant of the circle (the moon) in the sky upper right. These lines are extremely faint and partly drawn over; our reading is conjectural.
DanteLines 3-4 are written in the lower half of the circle (the moon) in the sky upper right.
DreamThe word is extremely faint and drawn over; our reading is conjectural. Butlin 812.86 reads lines 3-4 as "dante['s dream?]."

desc.objtitle: Beatrice on the Car with Matilda and DanteDante and Matilda on the Banks of the River Lethe, Object 90 (Butlin 812.87)
Beatrice Addressing Dante from the CarBeatrice Addresses Dante from the Car, Object 91 (Butlin 812.88)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "24" and "Pg Canto 29" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Harlot and the Giant, Object 92 (Butlin 812.89)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "30" top right, and "N 36 next at p 92" top center. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

lg.l: P-g. Canto 32The number in ink is offset a little to the left of its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle: The Spiral Stairway, Object 93 (Butlin 812.91)

lg.l: Paradiso Canto 19The inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased. Our reading of the first word is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: Dante Adoring ChristDante in Adoration of Christ, Object 94 (Butlin 812.90 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "96" top left, "N 43 next at p 33 Vanni Fucci 24" and "Vanni Fucci" partly erased along the left margin, and "Canto 23 Paradiso" partly erased along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Recording Angel, Object 95 (Butlin 812.92)

lg.l: PARA 67 v 65This inscription is extremely faint; our reading is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: Dante and Beatrice in the Constellation of Gemini and the Sphere of Flame, Object 96 (Butlin 812.93)
Saint Peter Appears to Beatrice and Dante, Object 97 (Butlin 812.94)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "99" top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Saint Peter and Saint James with Dante and Beatrice, Object 98 (Butlin 812.95)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "105" (or possibly "103") top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: Saint Peter and Saint James with Dante and Beatrice and with Saint John AlsoSaint John Joins the Other Saints and Dante and Beatrice, Object 99 (Butlin 812.96)

lg.l: Paradiso Canto 25This incription is extremely faint and has been painted over in wash. Our reading of the second word and the number is conjectural.

desc.objtitle: The Vision of the Deity from Whom Proceed the Nine SpheresThe Divine Essence from Whom Derive the Nine Spheres, Object 100 (Butlin 812.97)
Dante in the Empyrean Drinking at the River of LightDante in the Empyrean Drinks from the River of Light, Object 101 (Butlin 812.98)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "37" top right, "N49 next at p 16" top center, and "Hell Canto 26" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

desc.objtitle: The Queen of Heaven in Glory, Object 102 (Butlin 812.99)

objnote.p: The collection stamp of the Felton Bequest, National Gallery of Victoria, appears in the lower right corner.

lg.l: MaryThe word is inscribed above the head of the large kneeling figure, upper center.
SunThe word is inscribed in the circle upper right.

SceptreLookingThe first word is written just to the left of the scepter held in the right hand of the large kneeling figure, upper center. The second word is written just above the looking glass held in her left hand. "Looking" may be followed by another word, probably "glass," but if so the word is obscured by the design.
LawsThe word is inscribed above the head of the large seated figure, above and to the left of the center of the design.
DominionThe word is inscribed above the head of the right-most seated figure.
corded roundThese two words are inscribed on the side of the book held by the large seated figure, above and to the left of the center of the design. Our reading of the second word is conjectural.

HomerAris totleBibleThe first word is written on the open book to the left of the seated figure seen in profile, just left of the center of the design. The second word ("Aristotle") is written on the open book below and to the left of the right-most seated figure. The third word is written on the side of the book held by this same figure.
Chaind roundThis line is written just below the book held by the right-most seated figure. These two words form a syntactic unit with the final word in line 7.
